questions.question: What is the mean of a data set?
options: The middle value
The sum of all values divided by the number of values
The most frequent value
None of the above
questions.explanation: The mean is the sum of all values divided by the number of values in the data set.

questions.question: What is the median of a data set?
options: The middle value when the data is arranged in ascending order
The average of all values
The value that occurs most frequently
None of the above
questions.explanation: The median is the middle value when the data is arranged in ascending order.

questions.question: What is the mode of a data set?
options: The most frequent value
The average of all values
The middle value
None of the above
questions.explanation: The mode is the most frequent value in a data set.

questions.question: What is the variance of a data set?
options: The square of the standard deviation
The average of the differences from the mean
The sum of squared deviations divided by the number of observations
None of the above
questions.explanation: Variance is the sum of squared deviations from the mean, divided by the number of observations.

questions.question: What is the standard deviation?
options: The square root of the variance
The sum of the deviations from the mean
The average deviation
None of the above
questions.explanation: Standard deviation is the square root of the variance.

questions.question: What is a probability distribution?
options: A table showing all possible outcomes
A function that describes the likelihood of different outcomes
A set of events
None of the above
questions.explanation: A probability distribution describes the likelihood of different outcomes in a random experiment.

questions.question: What is the normal distribution?
options: A bell-shaped curve that is symmetric about the mean
A uniform distribution
A distribution with a skewed shape
None of the above
questions.explanation: The normal distribution is a bell-shaped curve that is symmetric about the mean.

questions.question: What is a z-score?
options: The number of standard deviations a value is from the mean
The variance of a data set
The mean of a data set
None of the above
questions.explanation: A z-score measures how many standard deviations a value is from the mean.

questions.question: What is a correlation coefficient?
options: A measure of the relationship between two variables
The slope of a regression line
The mean of a data set
None of the above
questions.explanation: The correlation coefficient measures the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables.

questions.question: What is a regression line?
options: A straight line that best fits the data points
A curve that represents the trend in the data
The average of all values
None of the above
questions.explanation: A regression line is a straight line that best fits the data points in a scatter plot.

questions.question: What is the central limit theorem?
options: The sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as the sample size increases
The mean of the sample is equal to the population mean
The variance of the sample is the same as the population variance
None of the above
questions.explanation: The central limit theorem states that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as the sample size increases.

questions.question: What is hypothesis testing?
options: A method for testing the validity of a hypothesis using sample data
A method for calculating the variance
A way of estimating the population mean
None of the above
questions.explanation: Hypothesis testing is a method used to test the validity of a hypothesis using sample data.

questions.question: What is a p-value?
options: The probability of observing the data given that the null hypothesis is true
The variance of the data
The probability of a type II error
None of the above
questions.explanation: The p-value is the probability of observing the data given that the null hypothesis is true.

questions.question: What is a type I error?
options: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true
Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false
Both a and b
None of the above
questions.explanation: A type I error occurs when we reject the null hypothesis when it is actually true.

questions.question: What is a type II error?
options: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true
Both a and b
None of the above
questions.explanation: A type II error occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false.

questions.question: What is the chi-square test used for?
options: Testing the relationship between two categorical variables
Testing the difference between two means
Testing the variance of a population
None of the above
questions.explanation: The chi-square test is used to test the relationship between two categorical variables.

questions.question: What is the null hypothesis?
options: The hypothesis that there is no effect or no difference
The hypothesis that there is a significant effect
The hypothesis that the sample mean equals the population mean
None of the above
questions.explanation: The null hypothesis is the hypothesis that there is no effect or no difference.

questions.question: What is the alternative hypothesis?
options: The hypothesis that there is a significant effect or difference
The hypothesis that there is no effect
The hypothesis that the sample mean equals the population mean
None of the above
questions.explanation: The alternative hypothesis is the hypothesis that there is a significant effect or difference.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a confidence interval?
options: To estimate a range of values for a population parameter
To calculate the sample mean
To calculate the sample variance
None of the above
questions.explanation: A confidence interval is used to estimate a range of values for a population parameter.

questions.question: What is a t-distribution?
options: A probability distribution that is used when the sample size is small and the population variance is unknown
A normal distribution
A uniform distribution
None of the above
questions.explanation: A t-distribution is used when the sample size is small and the population variance is unknown.

questions.question: What is a sample?
options: A subset of a population
The entire population
A type of probability distribution
None of the above
questions.explanation: A sample is a subset of a population that is used to make inferences about the population.

questions.question: What is the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics?
options: Descriptive statistics summarizes data, while inferential statistics makes predictions about a population based on a sample
Descriptive statistics makes predictions, while inferential statistics summarizes data
There is no difference
None of the above
questions.explanation: Descriptive statistics summarizes data, while inferential statistics makes predictions about a population based on a sample.

questions.question: What is the probability of rolling a 3 on a fair six-sided die?
questions.explanation: The probability of rolling a 3 on a fair six-sided die is 1/6.

questions.question: What does it mean for events to be mutually exclusive?
options: They cannot occur at the same time
They always occur at the same time
They are independent of each other
None of the above
questions.explanation: Mutually exclusive events cannot occur at the same time.

questions.question: What is Bayes' theorem used for?
options: Calculating conditional probabilities
Finding the mean of a distribution
Testing a hypothesis
None of the above
questions.explanation: Bayes' theorem is used to calculate conditional probabilities.

questions.question: What is the Law of Large Numbers?
options: As the sample size increases, the sample mean approaches the population mean
The mean of a sample is always equal to the population mean
As the sample size decreases, the sample mean approaches the population mean
None of the above
questions.explanation: The Law of Large Numbers states that as the sample size increases, the sample mean approaches the population mean.

questions.question: What is a Bernoulli trial?
options: An experiment with only two possible outcomes
An experiment with multiple outcomes
An experiment with a fixed probability
None of the above
questions.explanation: A Bernoulli trial is an experiment with only two possible outcomes, often referred to as success or failure.
